fr:title.text: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Idempotent monad containers are almost trivial

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monad T is idempotent when T \eta = \eta T, which for monad containers immediately gives us \iota = s for all s : S, and hence S is contractible.

Another equivalent condition for a monad T to be idempotent is that \text {Id} is a distributive law TT \Rightarrow TT. For monad container distributive laws this implies futher that all positions are equal, so the set P\ \iota is subsingleton.
Here's a compilation of monad container examples for reference.

Classes:
Cartesian
Idempotent
Commutative
Affine
Representable

Specific monad containers:
Maybe
State
Reverse State - just a curiosity, only definable in a theory with unrestricted fixed points

Let S \triangleright P be a container. A monad container (or mnd-container) on S \triangleright P is given by the following data: \begin {align*} \iota &: S\\ \sigma &: \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to S) \to S\\ \text {pr} &: \prod _{\{s : S\}} \prod _{\{f : P\ s \to S\}} P\ (\sigma \ s\ f) \to \sum _{p : P\ s} P\ (f\ p) \end {align*} For which the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ \iota \ (\lambda \_ . a ) &= a\\ \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) &= a\\ \sigma \ (\sigma \ a\ f)\ (\lambda p . g\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\ (\text {pr}_2\ p)) &= \sigma \ a\ (\lambda p . \sigma \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_1\ p) &= \text {pr}_1\ p\\ \text {pr}_1\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_1\ p)\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ (\text {pr}_2\ p) \end {align*} We abbreviate \pi _1 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_1 and \pi _2 \circ \text {pr} as \text {pr}_2. The last three laws hold up to the "associativity" law for \sigma .
